Re “A Final and a Beginning,” March 3: It is with bittersweet nostalgia and mixed emotions that I read the recounting of the 1963 N.C.A.A. championship men’s basketball game in which Loyola an...
docs.lead_paragraph:
To the Sports Editor:
 
Re “A Final and a Beginning,” March 3: It is with bittersweet nostalgia and mixed emotions that I read the recounting of the 1963 N.C.A.A. championship men’s basketball game in which Loyola and Cincinnati were each made up predominantly of black players.

docs.snippet:
Writers who covered the Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories. 

   
Jonathan Haynes was a senior point guard — a nice college player, no premier N.B.A. prospect — running the offense ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
Writers who covered the Big East Tournament at Madison Square Garden share their favorite memories. 

 
Jonathan Haynes was a senior point guard — a nice college player, no premier N.B.A. prospect — running the offense for Villanova in his final conference game. He made it count for something, too, with nine assists and only one turnover in 35 minutes as the Wildcats defeated Connecticut to win the 1995 Big East tournament.

headline.main: Year After Year, Held Rapt By Drama on a Huge Stage | One Moment, Many Times Over

docs.snippet: It is a particular pleasure, as a woman, to get to edit a men’s issue. In fact, it is the great pleasure of journalism — and by extension of being a reader — to be able to step outside one’s own world and dive into anot...
docs.lead_paragraph:
It is a particular pleasure, as a woman, to get to edit a men’s issue. In fact, it is the great pleasure of journalism — and by extension of being a reader — to be able to step outside one’s own world and dive into another as an interested outsider. This month we feature a wonderfully diverse array of men, all admirable in distinct and varied ways.
 
The cover shoot of the breakout star Matthias Schoenaerts was, for our seasoned team — the brilliant Bruce Weber, who has shot many a handsome, famous man, and also our entertainment director, Lauren Tabach-Bank, who has coddled many a star on a photo shoot — a charmed experience in which they were enthralled by the energy and realness of this actor, who having worked mostly in his native Belgium did not seem like so many of his slick, packaged and protected Hollywood peers. (Witness the picture of the crew cuddled in bed with Schoenaerts and see the video Weber made on the actor.)

docs.snippet: When a team is about to play its first game of the season, and the owner publicly states that anything less than a trip to the Eastern Conference finals would be a disappointment, pressure is created that is hard to live up to. For the Brooklyn Ne...
docs.lead_paragraph:
When a team is about to play its first game of the season, and the owner publicly states that anything less than a trip to the Eastern Conference finals would be a disappointment, pressure is created that is hard to live up to. For the Brooklyn Nets, who invested heavily in putting together a winning team in their first season since their move from New Jersey, the pressure created by the team’s owner Mikhail Prokhorov has seemingly distracted from what has otherwise been a successful move for both the Nets and Brooklyn.
 
In a sense, for anyone to talk about this season as a disappointment for the Nets is to ignore their recent history. Currently in line to be the No. 4 seed in the Eastern Conference, the Nets will almost assuredly make the playoffs for the first time since 2006-7, which was the last time the team finished with a .500 record. After years of being among the worst in the N.B.A. in home attendance, the Nets have filled 94.8 percent the Barclays Center’s seats on average for a total attendance of 583,228 through Friday.

headline.main: Nets Make Full Effort To Fit Into Brooklyn

docs.snippet:
How a former professional basketball player from Stockholm has turned an amateur interest in fragrance into the cult brand of the fashion world.  Go to interactive slide show -> 
   
With his lanky 6-foot-5 frame and sleeves of 1920s-era t...
docs.lead_paragraph:
How a former professional basketball player from Stockholm has turned an amateur interest in fragrance into the cult brand of the fashion world. Go to interactive slide show -> 
 
With his lanky 6-foot-5 frame and sleeves of 1920s-era tattoos, Ben Gorham doesn’t look like your average perfumer. In fact, when the former professional basketball player first presented his fragrances in Paris seven years ago, a French journalist sniffed, “What gives you the right to do perfumes?” Gorham, whose Byredo line now has a devoted following that generates $30 million in global sales, smiles as he recalls that early snub: “I was a wild card. But I’m very competitive. I can do one thing really obsessively.”

docs.abstract: World Baseball Classic’s unusual tiebreaker rules, which value run differential, play role in bench-clearing brawl late in Canada’s 10-3 victory over Mexico; seven players are ejected, and tournament officials are considering further discipline.
